ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: In this class, I developed insights into European Comparative Government. I loved reading from a variety of political and economic sources, to look at how Europe evolved over the past two centuries. You learn as much from this class as you put into it, so I would encourage any student taking this class to explore the readings to the fullest extent.
I learned a lot about the political science theory about Europe such as democratization, electoral systems, and party systems.
I learned a great deal about politics in Europe in both a historic and a contemporary context. The seminar covered many different subjects (voting systems, history, etc.).

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths - The readings, Professor Cameron, Seminar format (depending on the other students) 

Weaknesses - never got specific feedback on anything

The course was good at looking at the political science theories but I would have liked more of an overview of the political situations of the countries. This would have improved discussions in my opinion.

Strengths: Professor Cameron is incredibly accessible and very knowledgable. He is always wiling to meet outside of office hours and is always happy to talking through paper topics with you. The readings Professor Cameron chose were really interesting! 

Weakness: There is a lot of reading for this course, about a book a week (some weeks are lighter). Also at times, seminar would become a bit lecture-like but overall the seminar got better as the semester went on! (I attribute some of these weaknesses to the online format of the course).

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I like how the final paper was a research prospectus instead of a full research paper. Aside from being shorter and more to the point than a typical research paper, I liked how creative it allowed me to be. It was really an interesting assignment that I think would be beneficial even during non-COVID times.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, great course to take if you want to learn more about comparative government and Europe.

Professor Cameron is amazing and an incredibly kind and understanding professor. I wasn't thrilled by the material because I'm not particularly interested in comparative European politics, but that's more a matter of personal preference than it is a reflection on the course. The class is great, I'd probably just recommend it only if you're genuinely interested in comparative political and economic systems in Europe.
Yes, although I think having some knowledge about European politics before taking the class would help as well as interest in the topic should be a pre-requisite for my recommendation.

If you are interested in European Politics, I would suggest this course. The seminar does feel a bit like a lecture at times and some of the readings do get confusing (there is quite a bit of reading in this seminar), but if you are willing to do the readings then you will get a lot out of this course.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
